title-group.article-title: How Should Pensions in the UK Be Indexed?

p.mixed-citation: During the 1950s and 1960s uprating tended to occur every two or three years and increases were generally ahead of inflation.
Other components of the state pension have not increased at all. The old age addition paid to those over 80 has remained at 25 pence per week since 1971 and the Christmas bonus at £ 10 since 1972.

Analysing Family Expenditure Survey data, Johnson and Lambert ( 1989) calculate that income tax revenues grow around 1.6 to 1.7 times faster than incomes. Whitehouse (1991) finds for employees' National Insurance a comparable elasticity of 0.95, though the multiple for employers' contributions is around 1.25 times. The difference between the two elasticities for National Insurance arises primarily from the absence of an upper earnings limit to employers' contributions.

Concerning the impact of the thresholds see Dilnot and Webb (1988 and 1989). On the question of part-time employment and National Insurance contributions, see Disney and Szyszczak (1984) and Rice (1990).

On the impact of the 1986 Act on SERPS entitlements, see Creedy and Disney (1988). The well-known attempts to measure the cost of SERPS pre-1986 are Hemming and Kay (1982) and the paper underpinning DHSS (1985). The costs of SERPS post-1986 are discussed by the Government Actuary (1990) and by Fry, Smith and White (1990).

The guaranteed minimum pension (GMP) is calculated in a similar way to SERPS entitlements. However, a further indexation anomaly occurs when considering post-retirement increases in pension values. SERPS pensions in payment and notional GMPs are increased fully in line with prices. However, occupational pensions are obliged only to provide so-called limited price indexation, up to inflation of 5 per cent. The Government is responsible for indexing the notional GMP component of an occupational pension with inflation beyond 5 per cent.
See Creedy and Disney ( 1985) and Shimono and Tachibanaki ( 1985).

The very poorest lose all or most of their basic pension entitlement with little gain from paying less contributions, whilst the very richest would pay more in increased contributions than they would gain from the pension increase. This 'twin peaks' attribute of the net gains and losses can be observed from Figure 4 by rotating the diagram by about 450 clockwise, to net out contributions. This effect is magnified when account is taken of the greater longevity of richer pensioners.
Disney and Whitehouse (1990) discuss the determinants of occupational pension coverage.
